Posted By: TastetheJace (4/9/2013 6:57:45 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This is a cruel card. There are some cards that make people groan and moan whenever it hits the battlefield, and there's even a few who deserve such a reputation.  
  
If you go to a casual game with a jitte, you probably should expect to lose a few friends. It's not an instant win card, but it's so close to being one, and so powerful compared to the majority of the cards in the game, that with this card you basically rob and steal games, rather than win them.  
  
It's fine to own and to use in tournaments, but keep it away from the kitchen table.
posts.html:
This is a cruel card. There are some cards that make people groan and moan whenever it hits the battlefield, and there's even a few who deserve such a reputation.

If you go to a casual game with a jitte, you probably should expect to lose a few friends. It's not an instant win card, but it's so close to being one, and so powerful compared to the majority of the cards in the game, that with this card you basically rob and steal games, rather than win them.

It's fine to own and to use in tournaments, but keep it away from the kitchen table.

posts.post_content: This card wasn't played until Mirrodin's last sun set and it fell out of standard. Then it began being played in two, then four copies. Kamigawa wasn't a weak set, it had quite a few powerhouse cards, but Mirrodin wrecked up Magic so hard it took a while to see all the gems hidden in there.

Posted By: Claytoon (3/7/2013 3:03:00 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Something's wrong when creatureless decks run four copies of a Legendary equipment maindeck, just to nullify the opponent's... however I'm still glad it was printed because as with [Mindslaver](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mindslaver), it can be quite a fun card to lose against, since games involving it almost always turn out weird and convoluted and interesting. It also does a good job of making you feel, when it comes down, that you must have an out somewhere if only you can think of it. True enough at the end of the day it's just an artifact and one [Shatter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Shatter) will kill it... ah, the rock/paper/scissors beauty of magic. I still agree with Claov though, it could have been playtested more and tuned better.  
  
You know the worst thing though? In the book Toshi has TWO of these. Gah.
posts.html:

It also does a good job of making you feel, when it comes down, that you must have an out somewhere if only you can think of it. True enough at the end of the day it's just an artifact and one Shatter will kill it... ah, the rock/paper/scissors beauty of magic. You know the worst thing though? In the book Toshi has TWO of these. Gah.

Posted By: Goatllama (3/17/2013 6:00:40 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I've recently acquired one of these beauties and found a temporary home for it in my EDH/Commander deck until I get the cards to use it in Legacy. However, ever since I've played a tournament with it in Damia, Sage of Stone I don't think I ever want to take it out.  
  
Here are some used commanders that can be taken down with one swing from Jitte:  
Gaddock Teeg  
Edric, Spymaster of Trest  
Kaalia of the Vast  
Jhoira of the Ghitu  
Azami, Lady of Scrolls  
Captain Sisay  
Momir Vig, Simic Visionary  
Riku, of Two Reflections  
Sygg, River Guide  
Adun Oakenshield  
Arcum Daggson  
Anima, Soul of Elements (if you catch him small enough, or after a board wipe)  
Kira, Great Glass Spinner (granted you need at least 3 counters to kill her, but you're not losing any cards to do so).  
And those are just the tip of the iceberg of 2 toughness commanders that people use, not to mention utility creatures that can be off'd very easily.   
  
Jitte is an absolutely brilliant utility card: disruption, pump and emergency life gain... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
